metadata.case_name: Firestone Tyre & Rubber Co. (P) Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Subramaniam was employed as a van driver by Firestone Tyre & Rubber Co. (P) Ltd. since 1953. One of his duties was transportation for delivery of company products.

On May 28, 1963, Subramaniam set out to deliver tyres covered by six invoices to diverse addresses. Invoices Nos. 13815 and 13816 concerned eight tyres (4 per invoice) of specification 8.25 x 20 Tran. H.D.Nyl. 12-PR.

Subramaniam took delivery of the tyres, signed the six invoices, locked the tyres in his van with a key which he claims never left his possession, and set out with M.V. Das (packer/scooter driver) by his side in the driver's cabin, soon after lunch break.
At about 3.15 p.m. on May 28, 1963, Subramaniam telephoned the company office that two tyres from the two invoices were short. He was asked to return at once.
On return, tyres with him were unloaded and counted: short by two. Immediate check of stock held: no excess. Subramaniam maintained tyres were shortloaded or lost/stolen on the way.

After investigation, charge-sheet served on Subramaniam for misconduct: Theft, fraud or dishonesty in connection with employer's business or property, with full details, time and place of enquiry, right to defend through workman, produce evidence, cross-examine witnesses. Suspended pending enquiry.

Enquiry held by Mr. R.M. Coyajee, Industrial Relations Officer. Four witnesses for Company, two for Subramaniam examined. Company filed 20 documents, Subramaniam 2. Coyajee found charge proved, submitted minutes.
Manager, Southern Division informed Subramaniam of conviction of guilt, tentatively decided to dismiss, asked to show cause. Subramaniam showed cause, but dismissed.

Tyre & Rubber Company's Employees Union raised dispute. Referred by Government of Andhra Pradesh on February 7, 1964: 'Whether the dismissal of Shri K. Subramaniam, van Driver by the employers of Firestone Tyre & Rubber Co. (P) Ltd., Hyderabad is justified? If not, to what relief is he entitled?'

Labour Court (Presiding Officer, Hyderabad) award dated November 23, 1964: Set aside dismissal after finding enquiry opposed to natural justice and conclusion perverse. Ordered reinstatement without back wages.
Subramaniam's letter dated May 30, 1963: Reiterated supplied shorter number of tyres than in invoices.
In enquiry, Subramaniam stated he would state his case fully.

legal_issues.text: Whether the domestic enquiry was conducted properly in accordance with principles of natural justice.
Whether the conclusion of the domestic enquiry that the charge of misconduct was proved was perverse.
Whether the Labour Court was justified in setting aside the dismissal and ordering reinstatement without back wages.

petitioner_arguments.text: None of the Tribunal's grounds for holding enquiry invalid has validity: No compulsion to take explanation before charge-sheet; statements of preliminary enquiry not part of record or basis of conclusion; minutes not needed as workman present; evidence of Das properly considered.
Examining delinquent first permissible where accusation based on record or admitted facts, or to narrow issues; no prejudice caused; procedure fairer here.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen; Sur Enamel Stamping Works Ltd. v. Their Workmen; Meenglas Tea Estate v. Its Workmen; Associated Cement Companies v. Their Workmen; Central Bank of India Ltd. v. Karunamoy Banerjee (followed/distinguished)

petitioner_arguments.text: Management entitled to rely on loaders' evidence supported by Subramaniam's repeated admissions of checking tyres at loading; Tribunal exceeded by re-appreciating evidence.

respondent_arguments.text: Enquiry opposed to principles of natural justice and conclusion perverse: Held immediately after investigation without workman's explanation; workman examined/cross-examined before evidence against him; no copies of preliminary statements or enquiry minutes supplied; Das's evidence not properly considered.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen; Sur Enamel Stamping Works Ltd. v. Their Workmen; Meenglas Tea Estate v. Its Workmen; Associated Cement Companies v. Their Workmen

court_reasoning.text: No principle compels explanation before charge-sheet if prima facie fault after preliminary enquiry; done here without disadvantage to workman.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Calling explanation beforehand could fish for defence.

court_reasoning.text: Preliminary statements not in enquiry record or basis of conclusion; minutes unnecessary as workman present and could inspect; equated wrongly to Art. 311 enquiries.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Every opportunity afforded: informed of charge, cross-examined witnesses, led evidence, show cause on findings.

court_reasoning.text: Examining delinquent first not invariable rule; permissible on record/admitted facts or to narrow issues without prejudice; facts here different from cited cases; no objection or disadvantage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Procedure fairer here; ordinarily evidence first, but clear case allows reverse.

court_reasoning.text: Das supported shortloading claim; management entitled to disbelieve Subramaniam/Das and accept loaders' evidence plus Subramaniam's admissions of checking.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal cannot re-appreciate evidence if enquiry proper.

holdings.text: Domestic enquiry was properly conducted in accordance with principles of natural justice.
Tribunal erred in holding enquiry conclusion perverse and in re-appreciating evidence; limited to checking enquiry propriety.
Examining delinquent before management witnesses permissible in clear cases without prejudice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Lay down rule that evidence against delinquent must be led before questioning him; not invariable, inapplicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sur Enamel Stamping Works Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Lay down rule that evidence against delinquent must be led before questioning him; not invariable, inapplicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Meenglas Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Lay down rule that evidence against delinquent must be led before questioning him; not invariable, inapplicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Associated Cement Companies v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Lay down rule that evidence against delinquent must be led before questioning him; not invariable, inapplicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Bank of India Ltd. v. Karunamoy Banerjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Enquiry proper where clerk questioned first on admitted fault before formal evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Tribunal wrongly equated domestic enquiry to Art. 311 enquiries; not applicable.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Labour Court award set aside; dismissal of Subramaniam upheld as justified. No order as to costs. Company stated wages paid pendente lite will not be recovered.
outcome.relief_granted: Dismissal stands; no reinstatement or back wages.

key_quotes.text: "It cannot be an invariable rule in all cases. The situation is different where the accusation is based on a matter of record or the facts are admitted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies exception to rule on order of evidence in domestic enquiries.

key_quotes.text: "All that the Tribunal could do was to see that the enquiry was properly conducted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits Tribunal's role; no re-appreciation of evidence.

key_quotes.text: "The Management refused to believe Subramaniam even though he was supported by Das. This the Management was entirely within its right in doing."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms management's prerogative to accept/reject evidence.
